Instrument.name: Gravitational Wave Experiment for ULY
Instrument.description:
The Gravitational Wave Experiment for ULY is designed to detect low-frequency gravitational waves by utilizing Doppler tracking of the Ulysses spacecraft. Since the optimal size for a gravitational wave detector is the wavelength itself, this experiment requires the vast interplanetary dimensions, particularly in the mHz frequency band. Ulysses’ trajectory provides the ideal conditions for this experiment, with its measurements aiming to achieve the most sensitive detection of gravitational waves in this frequency range to date.
The primary noise source affecting the experiment is the fluctuations in the refractive index of interplanetary plasma. This imposes strict timing constraints on the experiment, especially near solar opposition. The experiment targets a fractional frequency change accuracy of 3.0 x 10^-14 over integration periods of about 1000 seconds.
The instrumentation for the experiment is distributed across the spacecraft’s radio systems and the ground stations of the Deep Space Network, along with the Medicina station. Preliminary analysis of data collected during Ulysses' first opposition test has already provided valuable insights into the experiment’s performance.
